column1: Roswell is a city in north Fulton County
column2: Georgia
column3: United States. In the official 2010 U.S. Census it had a population of 88
column6: making Roswell the state's eighth-largest city. A suburb of Atlanta
column7: Roswell has an affluent historic district.

column2: while on a trip to northern Georgia
column3: Roswell King passed through the area of what is now Roswell and observed the great potential for building a cotton mill along Vickery Creek. Since the land nearby was also good for plantations
column4: he planned to put cotton processing near cotton production.

column2: King returned to build a mill that would soon become the largest in north Georgia – Roswell Mill. He brought with him 36 African slaves from his own coastal plantation
column3: plus another 42 skilled carpenter slaves bought in Savannah to build the mills. The slaves built the mills
column7: and supporting buildings for the new town. The Africans brought their unique Geechee culture
column9: and religious traditions from the coast to north Georgia.

column1: King invited investors from the coast to join him at the new location. He was also joined by Barrington King
column2: one of his sons
column3: who succeeded his father in the manufacturing company. Archibald Smith was one of the planters who migrated there to establish a new plantation
column4: also bringing enslaved African Americans from the coastal areas.

column1: Shortly after 1832 a survey of the area  was conducted by Nathan Crawford Barnett as part of the Cherokee Purchase in preparation for the sixth state administrated land lottery culminating in the Cherokee removal.Barrington Hall (the home of Barrington King)
column2: Smith Plantation (the home of Archibald Smith) and Bulloch Hall (the childhood home of President Theodore Roosevelt's mother
column3: Mittie Bulloch) have been preserved and restored. They are now open to the public. According to the 1850 Slave Schedules
column5: together with the next three largest planters
column7: 51% of the total 378 slaves held in Roswell District. Archibald Smith had a 300-acre (1.2 km2) cotton plantation. According to the 1850 Census
column8: Barrington King held 70 slaves. Half of these slaves were under the age of 10. These slaves worked in Barrington's household. Barrington King "leased" or "rented" some of his adult male slaves to the Roswell Manufacturing Company
column9: but they did not work around the mill machinery.

column1: The Roswell area was part of Cobb County when first settled
column2: and the county seat of Marietta was a four-hour (one-way) horseback ride to the west. Since Roswell residents desired a local government
column3: they submitted a city charter for incorporation to the Georgia General Assembly. The charter was approved on February 16

column1: By the time of the Civil War
column2: the cotton mills employed more than 400 people
column3: mostly women. Given settlement patterns in the Piedmont region
column4: they were likely of Scots-Irish descent. As the mill increased in production
column5: so did the number of people living in the area.

column2: the city was captured by Union forces under the leadership of General Kenner Garrard. Under orders of General Sherman
column3: Garrard shipped the mill workers north to prevent them from returning to work if the mills were rebuilt. This was a common tactic of Sherman to economically disrupt the South. The mill was burned
column4: but the houses were left standing. The ruins of the mill and the 30-foot (9.1 m) dam that was built for power still remain. Most of the town's property was confiscated by Union forces. The leading families had left the town to go to safer places well before the Federal invasion
column5: and arranged for their slaves to be taken away from advancing Federal troops
column6: as was often the practice. Some slaves may have escaped to Union lines.

column2: Barrington King rebuilt the mills and resumed production. While many freedmen stayed in the area to work as paid labor on plantations or in town
column3: others migrated to Fulton County and Atlanta for new opportunities. The South suffered an agricultural depression resulting from the effects of the war and labor changes.

column2: the population of Cobb County decreased slightly from 14
column5: 814 in 1870. The proportion of African-Americans decreased more
column7: nearby Fulton County more than doubled in population
column10: 336. The effects of dramatic African-American migration can be seen by the increase in Fulton County from 20.5% slave in 1860 to 45.7% colored (Black) in 1870.

column2: the United States was in the midst of the Great Depression. The difficult economic conditions drove Milton County
column3: Roswell's neighboring county to the north (note: much of what is now Roswell was part of Milton County already)
column4: to merge in its entirety with Fulton County
column5: Roswell's neighboring county to the south. To facilitate the merger
column6: Roswell was ceded from Cobb County to become part of Fulton County. This became effective the 9th day of May in 1932. Roswell filed all legal records
column9: and the results of torts with the county clerk of Cobb before this date; with the county clerk of Fulton

column1: Roswell is now one of the largest cities in the state; its population has increased most steadily in the last 15 years.Lori Henry
column2: has served as mayor of Roswell since 2018. She is the first woman to assume the office.

column1: Roswell is located in northern Fulton County at 34°2′2″N 84°20′39″W (34.033896
column2: −84.344028). It is bordered to the north by Milton
column3: to the northeast by Alpharetta
column4: to the east by Johns Creek
column5: to the southeast by Peachtree Corners in Gwinnett County
column6: to the south by Sandy Springs
column7: to the west by unincorporated land in Cobb County
column8: and to the northwest by the city of Mountain Park and by unincorporated land in Cherokee County. The southern boundary of the city follows the Chattahoochee River.

column1: The Consulate-General of Honduras in Atlanta is located at Suite 3 in 600 Houze Way in Roswell. The city's largest employers are The Kimberly Clark Corporation
column2: North Fulton Regional Hospital
column3: Harry's Farmers Market
column4: and The City Of Roswell. A section of Route 400 between Roswell and Atlanta is known as the high tech corridor
column5: where many technology firms like Kimberly Clark have factories or offices. As of the 2006 census
column6: one third of Roswell's 5.000 registered business were home based. The largest industries were retail
column9: wholesale trade and health care.Many Roswell residents work in nearby Atlanta.Businesses with their headquarters in Roswell include Snorg Tees
column11: and Pharsalia Technologies. Roswell's economy is large enough to recruit franchises from many popular Georgia businesses like Moe's Southwest Grill
column12: Chick Fil A and Heel Sew Quik operate multiple locations in Roswell.In 2015
column13: Roswell was ranked 224 for economic growth among small American cities.
